title: Henri Estienne and the politics of linguistic borrowing in sixteenth-century France
abstractText: A study of vernacular writings of Henri Estienne (1531-98), with special references to his polemical attacks on linguistic borrowing from Italian into French, informed by a methodology derived from recent work in cognitive linguistics (specifically metaphor theory) that will account for Estienne's choice of a range of metaphors designed to characterise the process of linguistic borrowing, along with those that practise it, as unpatriotic, immoral and absurd. Close consideration will be given to the relationship between the semantic fields used in such metaphors and Franco-Italian relations during the period, and to Estienne's role in the development of linguistic purism.
